comments: It was a required live virtual seminar.
N/A

narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I learned extensively about the theories and history around populism throughout the world.

I learned to think more critically about the definition of "populism" and the various theories behind it. It allowed me to work with various definitions of the word to better analyze previous and current political figures and the way the galvanize people within a nation.

I gained a theoretical foundation in different definitions of populism and their implications in empirical analyses. We also learned to connect political rhetoric with mobilization and content, and analyze them in context of each other.

This course thoroughly examined the concept of populism and how it applies in both historical and modern contexts. I enhanced my understanding of the material, but also enhanced my critical thinking and writing skills.

I got a better understanding of the debates over populism, what it is, if it is a good thing. In doing so, I learned a great deal about political theory more generally. 

I got a good sense how to compare variants of populism in their national contexts and how this comparison tells us something about populism as a general phenomenon. This method is exceptionally useful for making valid theories about politics and life. I got a better theoretical understanding of how politics operates, as a result.

I learned a great deal about argument in this class, much more than I anticipated. Word economy, structure, use of evidence are all emphasized.

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: The other students are very insightful, which can be intimidating at times. The professor definitely isn't afraid to challenge students' ideas, so be prepared to defend your claims and don't back down from a good discussion.

Strengths: engaging readings, very manageable reading load
Weaknesses: sometimes required a bit of background knowledge to understand everything
Its a great class  the guest speakers are cool, and the readings are informative. I felt like it really did strengthen my understanding of populism and the pieces we read.
Strengths was the overall format of the seminar and class which was often student led with the professor serving as a moderator and often guiding the class with questions for us to think about
This course has an engaging structure that depends on the work of the individual to function. This creates an atmosphere conducive to learning and discussion.

The discussions were quite fruitful. The seminar had some really smart people in it who understood the readings and drew interesting connections and introduced new ideas. Paris does a good job stoking this fire. He pushes back and leads well to ensure it is burning hot. 

Paris also constructed the syllabus in a very logical way conducive to learning. He does what should be done in a good essay, telling you what the class will be about (populism), how we are going to study it (intellectual history and comparative politics), and leaves you to draw conclusions. 

Also, the papers are a great way to study something relevant to the class but something of your own idiosyncrasy.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Hard to sit through such a long seminar without ever getting a short break.

I feel like the virtual seminar worked really well! Professor Aslanidis did a great job of facilitating the discussion and encouraging us to think about the readings critically. However, I do think that a 2 hour long seminar on Zoom was a bit difficult for me.

I wonder if there could have been opportunities for pre-planned debates, or short student presentations throughout the semester to break up class format a bit. But I really enjoyed our discussions  and felt that Professor Aslanidis cultivated a really strong class dynamic.

The course depended on online readings that would have been online regardless of the pandemic and live discussions that were enriching even with the online format. Considering the circumstances, there is no area for improvement.

I find the virtual seminar format beneficial because I am one to speak a lot in class. So when those who don't speak disappear in the Zoom, I'm left with the professor and the other engaged students. I could see how some shy students might not like that.

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: If you're interested in populism, yes. Not a class to take just for another grade.

I don't think I would recommend this to another student. I do think that the reading load was very manageable and some of them were interesting, but I did not like the professor very much. He was nice and a fun guy, but I feel like he was not the most animated in our discussions. The two hours really dragged on, and I felt like much of his words were fairly monotone. I definitely think the content was interesting, but the professor did not make it the best class it could be.

Absolutely! If youre interested in populism as a concept as well as case studies of how its played out in the real world, this is a really wonderful class. Prof. Aslanidis provides really helpful feedback, and he pushed me to improve my own thinking and writing. Some of the theory could be intellectually challenging at times, but in a rewarding way. Also super timely given everything happening in the world.

I would recommend this course for anyone who has any remote interest in populism as with any full semester course on a specific subject, there is so much to unravel regarding the concept. This particular seminar here placed a unique focus each week on various themes regarding populism and how it can vary based on context. Workload mainly consisted of readings each week and were generally very interesting each week, with clear feedback given on assignment. The professor is furthermore very direct in being able to communicate what they are seeking, and thus I recommend this course for anyone who wants to place themselves in an informed-discussion heavy setting that allows them to explore populism.

Absolutely. This course not only broadened my understanding of populism, but altered my perception of academia entirely. I don't believe there are many courses that can achieve this level of enrichment, making this one an exemplary selection.

Absolutely. Any political science student should have a good grasp of populism. This course is a great way to study that and all related topics, which there are many. 

This course does not require any special background. One just has to be ready to argue their point.
Would absolutely recommend. Fascinating content matter and well-organized to address the topic from all angles. You also learn about methodology in a very clear and interesting way.
